As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. While most of Western Europe was engulfed in the Seven Years’ War, Constantinople was not, as the city emerged victorious at the end of the conflict. This brief respite allowed the city to regain its cultural and economic leadership, though this was short lived as war returned to Rome within three years. With an imperial presence in Rome as well as new empires in France and England, the Western Roman Empire would be split apart by a series of civil wars and political upheavals. In the meantime, the Byzantine Empire continued to grow, even if it was hindered by a lack of money, leadership, and troops. Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials of the Umayyad empire. It includes the largest mosaic of the Byzantine Empire, depicting religious and mythological figures, in the Byzantine style.

The Umayyad Empire fell in A.H. 636 to the Roman Emperor Theodosius the Great. Most mosaics from the Umayyad Empire were looted and melted down upon the fall of the realm. This mosaic includes an ancient depiction of the Holy Trinity. The mosaic is currently displayed in the Louvre.

A large proportion of the mosaics found in Syria, which has been part of the Arab peninsula since the 8th century, have been recovered only in recent times, when Syrian archaeologists started their research for economic and archaeological reasons. The title of "world's oldest airport" is disputed, but College Park Airport in Maryland, US, established in 1909 by Wilbur Wright, is certainly the oldest operational airport. It currently handles over 8 million passengers per year (mostly scheduled) and is the busiest general-aviation airport in the country.
There are also some other good contenders in Germany - Tegel is probably the oldest by some months, and the oldest still in operation (that we know, as Tegel was under a different name in its first year). Maybe Tegel itself could also claim the honor as well, as it was originally a military airport for the Luftwaffe during WW2, but that was in its time as a civilian aerodrome.

By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to make the decision to return to the island of Elba by June 1806. A fleet of twenty-five ships sailed from Genoa to escort him back to the island of Elba. But the fleet encountered the British expeditionary force under Admiral Byron in the Firth of Clyde, and after a brief engagement on 18 August 1806, the French fleet escaped for France. At the end of the month, Napoleon escaped from St Helena to Elba. He did not return to his island fortress on the shores of the Mediterranean Sea, though, but to his country mansion at Elba Castle. At the castle, he was finally restored to the rank of a grandee. He was received with great dignity. To mark the occasion, Napoleon invited the island’s “mercenaries” to lunch.

The Digimon franchise has long been fascinated by the idea of a mythological God that will soon return to life.

Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian is only spoken in the province of Valencia in Spain. People who live in Valencia claim to speak Valencian, but some Valencians claim to speak Spanish, whereas the former believe they speak Valencian. Valencia, along with Bilbao and Barcelona (formerly Barcelona de Catalunya), is one of Spain's most important tourism destinations, hosting many major international events such as the Eurovision Song Contest and the Gran Premio de España motor racing championship. Valencia is known as the "Pearl of the Mediterranean."

The Third (1919–23) and Fourth Aliyahs (1924–29) brought an additional 100,000 Jews to Palestine. In 1920, approximately 45,000 Jews fled Europe in large waves. During these years the Jewish population of Palestine grew from 50,000 to 120,000. By 1929, however, the Jewish population decreased to 67,000. The third aliyah was the first significant wave of immigrants during the British Mandate period.

The rise of Zionism in the mid-20th century also brought a significant number of Jewish refugees to Mandatory Palestine.

Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least two millennia back from the use of bronze (an ancient Chinese civilization used a special copper alloy that would bend but would not shatter). Copper is known to be extremely hard and will not rust, as long as it is not exposed to corrosive chemicals or sunlight. Copper is a great conductor of heat and is used in many electrical, electronic, chemical, and other machinery, and is used in many other applications.

History Copper was discovered to the ancient Greek, the Chinese, the Hebrews, the Incas, and the Aztecs. Copper was also known to the ancient Gauls (the ancient English people are also known as the Gauls), Carthaginians, and even Ancient Rome, which relied heavily on copper for copper work. In a number of countries, although being today generally considered similar institutions of higher learning across many countries, polytechnics and institutes of technology used largely differ in their educational focus from colleges. In these latter cases, many countries, even under the same name of "institution", have very different programs, degree curricula and general outlook on student outcomes.

A common name in most nations is an "College", however "Polytechnic" is a common term used throughout the world, especially in countries without a College level system. This term, however, is also referred to in the United States as simply "Technical School" and some jurisdictions (specifically, Canada and the United Kingdom) as simply "Technical Institution" or "Technical College".

The islands are at relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying: the lowest point in the islands is Holme Pierrepont on the River Mersey at 874m, while the highest point is the North Ronaldsay peninsula in Scotland at 950m. The islands have a maximum elevation of 1,000 metres, with the highest point near Dun Laoghaire (Coney Blaney) being 1,016m. The sea surrounding the islands is generally shallow.

The islands are mainly part of the North Dublin County Council and the South Dublin County Council, whose municipal bodies are collectively known as Greater Dublin Council. The islands are separated from Dublin by the East or Liffey Estuary and the Ross River Mouth.

Democratic Party candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters; an important subtlety is that these characters can appear in either inverted or upright positions. Inversions have a wider range than inversions.

These "special characters" are the most familiar and are used all the time; some are used only rarely ("cursive" or "handwriting" characters were often used for this purpose). Note that these characters are not alphabetically arranged. Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase usually occurs after vomiting and involves the gastric function, and therefore it is possible to prevent vomiting by the administration of antineoplastons.
The gastric phase consists of the absorption of nourishment via the gastric juice. Antineoplastons act directly on the gastric juice, i.e. they act inside the gastro-intestinal tract. Gastric antineoplastons act by preventing the gastric juice from being absorbed through the gastric-mesentery junction into the intestine; in other words, the absorption of food into the intestine by the gastric juice is prevented by the gastric antineoplastons.
A known gastric antineoplaston is a mixture of peptide derivatives, the composition of which is:
a. an inhibitor of the protein-lysine translocationase II

The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (over land and by air) from areas where they are native and are disrupting ecosystems from the South Pacific to the Amazon to the northern United States. Although few studies of invasive species have explored the ecological impact of invasions of nonnative plants and animals, it has been estimated that the loss of native flora in New England and the Gulf of Mexico combined to cost more than $1 billion annually. Many invasive species, especially those brought along by travel and tourism, negatively affect natural habitat, wildlife, and fisheries and can lead to human illnesses. The invasion of exotic plant species also threatens native habitats and increases susceptibility to diseases caused by exotic pathogens. In addition, many plant species spread from North America and Eurasia directly to the Mediterranean and to tropical areas. The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind was the 1584 edition of Pico della Mirandola's Treatise on the Kingdom of Heaven. This work, which the Italian government found no use for, not only contained the best commentary available on Copernicus' works but was the forerunner of the Renaissance humanistic movement in Europe that would culminate in the philosophy of Galileo Galilei. It was also in Pico's work that Francis Bacon (1361–1626), founder of the Scientific Renaissance, published his treatise The History of Medicine. This history of medicine, however, has been viewed through the lens not only of Bacon's influence but with the aim of justifying Bacon's scientific achievements and therefore its failure to give the reader any insight into the true nature of the human soul.

The "Bleacher Bums" is a name given to fans, many of whom spend much of the day heckling, who sit in the lower level seating behind home base, where food, drink, and many other amenities are scarce. The "Bleacher Bums" name is derived from the slang term for "white trash" from the movie Deliverance.

Hanging out on the lower deck for the day? That's easy. No charge. The downside: sitting in a plastic chair and getting heckled by your neighbors and teammates. The upside: cheap beer, great atmosphere, and an actual view of the game.

The upper level of Petco is the equivalent of the suites found at a professional venue like Marlins Park, and it costs a pretty penny. The tickets will give you great location behind home plate, but they are in premium seating behind the infield with bad acoustics. Also pricey, but with excellent view.

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite this, the phonautograph is less noted in the history of phonics today than the phonograph, as it took seven years longer to achieve similar levels of success, and most educators still believe that teaching phonics by means of writing is a more efficient means of instruction (Lang et al., 1999). Nonetheless, phonics is essential to the effective use of reading and writing programs, and it remains important on many levels. This paper will discuss the major elements that need to be considered before deciding to use a phonics program, and the importance of a variety of elements in a program including vocabulary construction, phonemic awareness, spelling, pronunciation, fluency and comprehension.

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the godess of love. The Hesiodic Catalogue of Women: Graecus is a work in the Hesiodic corpus.

In this catalogue of Greek women the women are distinguished according to the number of lovers they had.

The book begins with the names and titles of women and is followed by a table of their lovers and the dates when they met and married.  Some of the women who had no lovers numbered from zero to ten in the catalogue and all those who ranked more than ten were listed by names only.  A number indicating the number of lovers a woman had is given on the following lines.

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth, survival, and development, among other life functions. While energy is present at every scale, energy is a scarce component, especially at low temperatures. During cryoabundance events such as solar flares, gamma-ray bursts, or the presence of an extremely energetic object (such as a supernova), many aspects of astrophysical phenomena are associated with the increase in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) intensity.

In addition to the cosmic microwave background (CMB) emission, the Sun and the interstellar medium also produce electromagnetic emissions including visible and ultraviolet light. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism, Zoroastrianism, Christianity and Judaism to Arabic Islam. The Rashidun Caliphate later ruled the central Asian provinces of Fars (northwest Iran), Khorasan (west Iran), and Mazandaran (southwest Iran) for over a millennium, ruling from an area from Khorasan (modern day Iran) to Bukhara (modern day Uzbekistan).

Islam spread to the area of the modern-day Central Asian states of Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Kyrgyzstan in the 11th through the 15th centuries, with the greatest influence in Sogdia (modern day Russia) followed by the Magyar Turkestan (modern day Turkey).

Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated for the most part by miniatures, and the mediums used for this included painted, coloured and printed. It was popular in many parts of Europe, and throughout the world, for centuries. At the height of its popularity it was used in every corner of the continent. The earliest carolingian artists were a very varied group, with only a minor difference in technique between them. Some were trained in Western art styles, whilst others were very unusual. Their style of work would have come about from being in and around the court, and their work would have been used to illustrate books. Some carolingian work is very colourful and exuberant, others are quite dark and solemn.

The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid constitute our only evidence of the mind of a poet, of any great nature, in classical times. Virgil made the poet, by the use of the Greek language, accessible to a world which had lost the language of its poets. Through his productions, in the manner of Homer, Virgil taught the modern world Latin prose and poetry, and made Greek literature more accessible to Greeks.

The Eclogues form a singularly beautiful work of art, in which the poet seems to have employed his great powers in the making of what is the greatest work of art that has existed to date. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for the launch.

But the same year, the Americans announced their intent to put a man into space without first training him.

After much delay and a lot of work at NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston, the Soviet Union announced on Sept. 28, 1959, that Yuri Gagarin had made the journey. A small, single-engine U.S.-built rocket put a capsule into orbit, carrying the cosmonaut onto the first flight into space.

With the announcement, "the space race for the first human to carry a weightless payload into space" began, the Houston Chronicle reported at the time.

Gagarin's rocket was a U.S.-built plane built for the Air Force, called "White Knight."

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the main portion of the island is an inactive volcano) that have made it inhospitable to human life. The surface area of Saint Helena, including the island's three inhabited regions, is 15.8 km2 (6.4 sq mi).

The island of Saint Helena is the second smallest British overseas territory by total area, and the fourth smallest island in the world based on its surface area. It has an area of 42 m (137 ft.) by 17 m (57 ft.) and an area that is 3.7% land. Its shoreline is approximately 160 m (550 ft) from the north-east to the south-west.

The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) apart. There are three lines, each 50 yards long by 15 yards (13 m) high.

To run a play, the ball must be held between the front shoulders of one player on each team. The opposing team may snap the ball behind the play-side end-zone line, but this is not considered a legal punt to the quarterback – instead it must be placed behind the end-zone line, on or over the sideline nearest to the receiving team’s goal-line.

Each team has a 25-yard (23 m) downfield boundary. The quarterback has the option of playing it on his own or taking advantage of the protection and running around to the sidelines. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with all foreign air carriers or on their airplanes being ordered to leave the United States.
On April 10, 1942, President Roosevelt instructed Attorney General Frank Kelley to have the names of such air carriers and their crews removed from the list.
The directive of April 10, 1942, was sent to all Attorney Generals, Chief of Police, and other police officials, requesting that they inform their subordinates that "civil disturbance laws, particularly the Unlawful Disorderly Organizations Act of 1916, shall not be used except as a measure of last resort."

In 1942 the Bureau compiled a list of pilots, first officers, and flight mechanics of Japanese ancestry, or those who were known to be Japanese, who had flown in the United States.  This was a follow up to President Roosevelt's directive of 1941 calling for the list of Japanese aircraft owners.

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia. An especially popular method of hybridisation involves mating two closely related species which are native to a particular geographical region. This method of hybridisation has been found to have significant detrimental impacts on plant and animal species within the target area. For example, if the hybridised animal is an exotic species introduced into a natural ecosystem or if the hybridised animal is a non-native species introduced into a non-native habitat. The impact of hybridisation may be significant and include, but are not limited to alteration of native seed sources, changes in the distribution, life history, ecology and survival of native species as well as alterations in the host plant or host habitat resulting in the decline of species in the area.

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, believed all things were caused by God, and could be explained away by deistic explanations not requiring belief in a god. In particular, in his essay “Agrarian Justice and the Rights of Man,” Paine called deism “the common faith of the ancient world” (Paine, The Rights of Man; New England Historic Publication Society, Boston, 1967). It has been called “the most brilliant and practical argument ever made for the removal of Christianity from the sphere of government” (Abedi, 2004, P. 4, citing William Godwin).

BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school's move to the independent NCAA Division I in 2011. Beginning in 2012, BYU competed in the Western Athletic Conference. In 2016, BYU joined the Pacific-12 Conference, which consists of five members, BYU, USC, Oregon State, Arizona State and Washington State. In 2018, BYU moved to the Mountain West Conference, which consists of 11 members; BYU, San Diego State, UNLV, Boise State, Colorado State, Hawaii, New Mexico, Fresno State, Nevada, New Mexico State, San Jose State and Wyoming.

Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.4 mph), according the US National Climate Data Center.

Montreal, the third-most-urbanized Canadian city, is also cold in the winter. After the snow melted in June, the average temperature was 3.5 degrees lower than in June.

While Montreal has had some intense summers (including two of the hottest summers on record), the average temperature in June 2016 was 5 degrees lower than the 20th century average.

Toronto gets the worst for the amount of snowfall in the winter months. It's snowed an average of 2.5 inches on average annually; an average of 5.4 inches in June; 5.1 inches in July and 5.2 inches in August.

Toronto has consistently had the coldest summer days on record. The hottest day on record is 54.5 degrees

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. This paper uses a new analytical framework to analyze Notre Dame football's cultural and institutional success, comparing it to other Protestant institutions and Catholic institutions, particularly those associated with professional football. Using a sample of major college football programs, the results suggest that a Protestant football program tends to have less success than a Catholic one, and that a Protestant program tends to have greater success than a Catholic one in the business and advertising industry. (SZ)

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical regions from which its borders are derived: the Rhône Valley, the Swiss-European Alps from the north, and the mountains and valleys of the Jura, such as the Jura- Alps, the Savoie, the Jura-Savoie and the Jura.

The Alps have a height between 8,000.0 and 10,500.0 m, and encompass more than 15,000 individual summits. Many of these summits are over 2,000 m. These summits are usually made of granite, and are sometimes crags and rock ridges with overhanging cliffs up to the highest points. The Jura is made of granitoids: granites, amphiboles, dolomites, gneisses and metamorphic rocks such as the granite and dolomites

Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) is just slightly more accurate than using the −18 °C (25 °F) warmest month (May).

Some people claim that the coldest day is in late January, but that is an inaccurate claim. The coldest day on Earth actually occurs in June, at −16.7 °C (−3.2 °F). If it is cold where you are, you probably don’t know if you’re in the winter, and it is likely that the city is not included in the chart unless it is included in both versions of the chart. If it’s still freezing (and likely snowing or raining) in January, just let your browser refresh the page a few times and you should see the city in the appropriate months.

Most precipitation in the Boston metro area occurs in the summer months

In December, Beyoncé along with a variety of other celebrities teamed up and produced a video campaign for "Demand A Plan", a bipartisan effort by former President Barack Obama and former Health and Human Services Secretary Secretary Kathleen Sebelius to urge Republicans in Congress to support bipartisan legislation that would ensure all Americans have access to affordable health insurance coverage. The video campaign's message was simple: "If you don't like your plan -- just get rid of it." The goal was clear -- remind Republican senators of their constituents' feelings on the issue and to work to pass a health care reform plan that would help millions of American families.

Beyoncé's message was perfectly timed -- with Donald Trump about to take office, as well as rumors that Republican senators could vote next week to overturn Obamacare, Beyoncé's video campaign was designed to encourage senators to work together to fix problems with the law.

Unfortunately, the video campaign failed. The next Tuesday, Senate Republicans voted to undo President Barack Obama

And because the Muslim community is a minority in Iraq and other countries where there are no current Muslim majorities, waqf may not have been fully restored but it is not, in fact, dormant either. Since Iraq’s Christians had some semblance of religious freedom, this may also have affected their status of waqf. In the past, a large crowd of locals have gathered to watch the lantern parade.

This year's event brought visitors from different places across Japan.

Visitors from the northern prefecture of Hokkaido have traveled over 500 miles to attend.

The number of lantern makers in Japan is decreasing and fewer people from other regions are making them, according to Toshiko Aoki, Japan's minister of culture, sports, science and technology.

According to Aoki, it's important for regional tourists to come to Japanese lanterns in order to ensure the traditions are carried on.

The lantern festival began about a century ago. Local children were asked to create lanterns for their schools.
